awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: GOALI: Detecting and Reconstructing Network Anomalies and Intrusions in Heavy Duty Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Heavy vehicles (e.g., trucks and busses) are a critical element of U.S. and worldwide logistics, often carrying cargo of high value or high risk (e.g., explosive liquids and gasses).  Heavy vehicles often have hundreds of Electronic Control Units (ECUs) that communicate over an internal network to carry commands (such as "engage the brakes") or share sensor data (such as the temperature of pressurized cargo unit carrying petroleum). ECUs with access to the communication network can send any message they want.  If the network or an ECU is compromised by an attack, the truck or a cargo container safety mechanism could malfunction. This project is gathering data from operational trucks to better understand communication among components of heavy vehicles and developing techniques to detect attacks in this environment.

The project is working to accomplish three main objectives: (1) Collect representative Controller Area Network (CAN) bus data from operational heavy vehicles, (2) Develop detection systems that can distinguish anomalous CAN bus network traffic, and (3) Test and verify the detection systems to reduce the number of false positives. The team is developing a log algebra to efficiently assess live CAN traffic using embedded devices with limited resources. Data is being gathered from truck traffic during highway operation, enabling the application of machine learning algorithms for anomaly detection. The team is evaluating the effectiveness of their intrusion detection techniques in their heavy vehicle testbed, using synthetic attacks against testbed ECUs and real-world CAN traffic data.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Heavy vehicles are part of the US Critical infrastructure as they provide the backbone of the us economy by moving goods and freight around the country. Heavy vehicles also make up most of the public transportation fleets and provide the vehicles necessary for school bussing. Commercial and specialty applications like fire engines and street sweepers are built on heavy vehicle technology. A common theme of modern heavy vehicle is the SAE J1939 in-vehicle network. This is a controller area network (CAN) based communication system that provides additional specificity to message format and meaning. Since these vehicles are important to our society and utilize a CAN bus, there exists a potential for cybersecurity vulnerabilities to exist, which, if exploited, could be detrimental to the operation of the vehicle. If these exploits were deployed at scale and affected many hundreds or thousands of trucks at once, the surface highway transportation system would become dysfunctional, and our lives would be disrupted.

At the core of the project is vehicle network data from the heavy vehicles. At first, this may seem easy to get, because the truck makers would have such data. However, the trucks driving down the road often have been modified through the addition of fleet telematics devices or federally mandated electronic logging devices. Many vehicle go through an upfitting process where the utility bodies and vocational packages are added to the rolling chassis from the truck maker?s factory. This means there was no consistent data available for researchers to examine the normal network traffic for heavy vehicles on the road. To address this issue, the project developed a low-cost, open-source data logger that could collect vehicle network traffic and securely store the data. 

With the collaboration with the National Motor Freight Traffic Association, Inc. (NMFTA), the GOALI partner for this project, the CAN logging devices were deployed to fleet carriers and utilized to capture CAN bus data during their operation. The CAN loggers were connected to vehicles of different year, make, and model. However, the live data collected during business operations were business sensitive, so the data is not releasable to the public. Instead, the NMFTA setup an internal research environment in their secure computing facility and made the data available to researchers who registered with them. There were over 4 billion messages collected and made available. A challenge with this controlled access research environment was the researcher had to request software tools to be installed by the system administrator. The data were not allowed to be exfiltrated, so the data needed for research results had to be exported through the system administrator.

Unrestricted data was also collected by researchers not operating a vehicle for business. Heavy vehicle assets for these data came from used truck dealerships, operators testing within their yard, trucks being used in training, and researcher owned vehicles. These data sets were made publicly available and utilized in research by multiple institutions.  Also, the data collection efforts enabled a noteworthy contribution to a CAN data collection workshop, where the data collected under this project were highlighted along with some other passenger car data sets. As of the workshop in November 2021, there were no other know public data sources for heavy vehicle network traffic. This research artifact has enabled the testing and validation of research efforts in the community. For example, data sets used by Kim et al. [1] included the Kenworth T270 data obtained under this program.

Collaborators under the direction of Dr. Indrakshi Ray at Colorado State University utilized the collected CAN data for intrusion detection algorithm research based on machine learning concepts. They were able to utilize the data sets to break down the messages according to parameter groups, source address and signal names. The data help them with a sense of realism for there approach and they were able to compare across different vehicle makes.

The graduate students working on this project participated in industry events like the CyberTruck Challenge. The research of designing secure systems to collect and store the CAN data from heavy vehicles prepared them well to interface with the industry engineers at the events. Upon graduation, the students transitioned to professional positions that utilized their skills and understanding of cybersecurity for heavy vehicles, thus adding to a necessary talent pool of cyber aware engineers in the heavy-duty vehicle industry.

References

[1] Sungwoo Kim, Gisu Yeo, Taegyu Kim, Junghwan "John" Rhee, Yuseok Jeon, Antonio Bianchi, Dongyan Xu, and Dave (Jing) Tian. 2022. ShadowAuth: Backward-Compatible Automatic CAN Authentication for Legacy ECUs. In Proceedings of the 2022 ACM Asia Conference on Computer and Communications Security (ASIA CCS ?22), May 30?June 3, 2022, Nagasaki, Japan. ACM, New York, NY, USA, 12 pages. https://doi.org/10.1145/3488932.3523263


Last Modified: 05/03/2022
Modified by: Jeremy S Daily

Image
  • Example heavy vehicle as a data source for network traffic to analyze
    Jeremy Daily
    Jeremy S Daily
    CyberTruck Challenge Research Vehicle
